content.text: State the equation for the gravitational force \(F\) between two point masses \(m_{1}\) and \(m_{2}\) that are separated by a distance \(r\). State the meaning of any other symbols you use
A satellite is in a circular orbit of radius \(R\) around a planet of mass \(M\)
Show that the period \(T\) of the orbit is given by
where \(k\) is a constant that depends on the value of \(M\). Explain your reasoning
Calculate the radius of the orbit
radius =   .........  m
State the two other conditions that must be met for the orbit to be geostationary
A satellite is in a circular orbit around the Earth with a period of 24 hours
The mass of the Earth is \(6.0 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\)
State two other physical properties of materials, apart from the density of a liquid, that can be used for measuring temperature
Calculate, to three significant figures, the final steady temperature indicated by the thermometer in the water
temperature =   .........  Â°C
Suggest one change that could be made to the design of the thermometer that would enable it to give a more accurate measurement of temperature

The thermometer is initially at \(23.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), as shown in Fig. 2.1. It is used to measure the temperature of an insulated beaker of water that is at \(37.4^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The bulb of the thermometer is inserted into the water, and the water is stirred until the reading on the thermometer becomes steady
The mass of water in the beaker is \(18.7 \text{g}\)
The mass of mercury in the thermometer is \(6.94 \text{g}\)
The specific heat capacity of water is \(4.18 \text{J} \text{g}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1}\)
The specific heat capacity of mercury is \(0.140 \text{J} \text{g}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1}\)
The glass of the thermometer and the beaker containing the water can be considered to have negligible heat capacity
Explain why the thermometer in Fig. 2.1 does **not** provide a direct measurement of thermodynamic temperature
Thermodynamic temperature \(T\) may be determined by the behaviour of a type of substance for which \(T\) is proportional to the product of pressure and volume
State the name of this type of substance
Fig. 2.1 shows a laboratory thermometer that is calibrated to measure temperature in degrees Celsius
The thermometer makes use of the fact that the density of mercury varies with temperature
State the defining equation for simple harmonic motion. Identify the meaning of each of the symbols used to represent physical quantities
The variation with displacement \(x\) from the equilibrium position of the velocity \(\nu\) of the object is shown in Fig. 3.2
State what is meant by damping
Assume that the damping does not change the angular frequency of the oscillations
On Fig. 3.2, sketch the variation with \(x\) of \(\nu\) when the amplitude of the oscillations is \(0.060 \text{m}\)
The oscillations of the object are now lightly damped
An object is suspended from a spring that is attached to a fixed point as shown in Fig. 3.1
The object oscillates vertically with simple harmonic motion about its equilibrium position
State what is indicated by the direction of an electric field line
On Fig. 4.1, draw five lines to represent the electric field in the region between the plates
Calculate the strength of the electric field between the plates
electric field strength =   .........  \(NC^{-1}\)
Fig. 4.1 shows a pair of parallel metal plates with a potential difference (p.d.) of \(2400 \text{V}\) between them
The plates are separated by a distance of \(4.6 \text{cm}\). The plates are in a vacuum
The proton is deflected by the electric field
On Fig. 4.2, draw a line to show the path of the proton as it moves through and out of the region of the electric field
A helium nucleus ( \(^4_2\mathrm{He})\) now enters the region of the electric field along the same initial path as the proton and travelling at the same initial speed
State and explain how the final speed of the helium nucleus compares with the final speed of the proton after leaving the region of the electric field
A moving proton enters the region between the plates from the left, as shown in Fig. 4.2
Calculate the charge \(Q_0\) on the capacitor at time \(t = 0\)
Calculate the current \(I_0\) in wire P at time \(t = 0\)
Calculate the time constant \(\tau\) of the discharge circuit
On Fig. 5.2, sketch a line to show the variation with \(t\) of the current \(I\) in wire P as the capacitor discharges
Explain why there is an induced e.m.f. across wire Q during the discharge of the capacitor
On Fig. 5.3, sketch a line to suggest the variation with \(t\) of the voltmeter reading \(V\)
A capacitor of capacitance \(470 \mu \text{F}\) is connected to a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(24 \text{V}\) in the circuit of Fig. 5.1
The two-way switch S is initially at position X
P and Q are identical long straight wires, each with a resistance of \(5.6 \text{k}\Omega\). These wires are placed near to, and parallel to, each other. Wire Q is connected to a voltmeter
At time \(t = 0\), switch S is moved to position Y so that the capacitor discharges through wire P
Use the letters in Fig. 6.1 to identify the faces that are perpendicular to the magnetic field
Explain how the steady Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) is developed between faces PQXW and SRYZ
State the meaning of the symbols \(n\), \(t\) and \(q\). You may refer to the letters in Fig. 6.1
n:
t:
q:
Suggest, with reference to the equation, why the slice of the material used in a Hall probe is thin
The magnitude of \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) is given by the equation
Fig. 6.1 shows a thin slice of semiconducting material used in a Hall probe
Current \(I\) passes through the slice in the direction shown
The slice is placed in a uniform magnetic field of flux density \(B\), so that two of its faces are perpendicular to the magnetic field
A steady Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) is developed between face PQXW and face SRYZ
The alternating voltage is applied across a resistor of resistance \(760\Omega\)
By considering the peak voltage, show that the maximum power dissipated by the resistor is \(46 \text{mW}\)
On Fig. 7.1, draw a smooth curve to show how the power \(P\) dissipated in the resistor varies with time \(t\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 40 \mu \text{s}\). Assume that \(P = 0\) when \(t = 0\)
Fig. 7.1
Use your line in (a)(ii) to explain why the mean power dissipated in the resistor is \(23 \text{mW}\)
A sinusoidal alternating voltage has a root-mean-square (r.m.s.) potential difference (p.d.) of \(4.2 \text{V}\) and a frequency of \(50 \text{kHz}\)
Explain what happens to the air surrounding the crystal
A second piezoelectric crystal is placed in the air near to the first crystal
Explain the effect of the surrounding air in **(b)**(i) on the second crystal
The alternating voltage in **(a)** is now applied to a piezoelectric crystal in air
State what is meant by the work function energy of a metal
Determine the number of photons incident on the surface per unit time
number per unit time =   .........  \(s^{-1}\)
Calculate the work function energy \(\Phi\) of the metal

Ultraviolet radiation of frequency \(1.36 \times 10^{15} \text{Hz}\) is incident, in a vacuum, on a metal surface. The power of the radiation incident on the surface is \(8.36 \text{mW}\). Photoelectrons are emitted with a maximum kinetic energy of \(3.09 \times 10^{-19} \text{J}\)
the maximum kinetic energy of the photoelectrons
the rate of emission of photoelectrons
The frequency of the radiation incident on the surface in **(b)** is increased while the power remains constant
State and explain the effect of this change on:
State what is meant by the luminosity of a star
Calculate the radiant flux intensity of the radiation from the star observed from the Earth. Give a unit with your answer
radiant flux intensity =   .........  unit   .........
Determine the radius of the star
radius =   .........  m

A star in the constellation Canis Major is a distance of \(8.14 \times 10^{16} \text{m}\) from the Earth and has a luminosity of \(9.86 \times 10^{27} \text{W}\). The surface temperature of the star is \(9830 \text{K}\)
Explain how the surface temperature of a distant star may be determined from the wavelength spectrum of the light from the star
random
spontaneous
State what is meant by:
State how Fig. 10.1 demonstrates that radioactive decay is random
On Fig. 10.1, draw the straight line of best fit
Show that the decay constant \(\lambda\) of carbon-15 is given by the magnitude of the gradient of your line in (b)(ii)
Use your line in (b)(ii) to determine \(\lambda\). Give a unit with your answer
Use your answer in (b)(iv) to calculate the half-life of carbon-15
half-life =   .........  s
A small sample of carbon-15 decays. The mass \(M\) of carbon-15 in the sample decreases with time \(t\)
Fig. 10.1 shows the variation with \(t\) of the value of \(\ln {(M / 10^{- 16}\mathrm{g})}\)
The equation for the decay of carbon-15 can be written as
State and explain how the mass of the products of the decay must compare with the mass of the carbon-15 nucleus
Carbon-15 ( \(^{15}_{6}\mathrm {C})\) is an isotope of carbon that undergoes radioactive decay to nitrogen-15 ( \(^{15}_{7}\mathrm {N})\) , which is a stable isotope of nitrogen
Radioactive decay is both a random and a spontaneous process
